IdiomsExpressions.first: Cost an arm and a leg

IdiomsExpressions.second: to creat a feeling of disgust or horror
to start again from the beginning
a job that won’t lead to anything else
the most helpful assistant or employee.
to betray someone = to not be loyal
to change one’s opinion or mind
to barely have enough money to survive
under severe strain = very anxious ( worried)
to miss class without an excuse
to have the possibility of success

PastSimpleExs.Ar: جاء علي إلى المدرسة الأسبوع الماضي.
PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: Ali came to school last week.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: Ali didn't come to school last week.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did Ali come to school last week?

PastSimpleExs.Negative: It was not cold last month.

PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: You lost the keys last week.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: You didn't lose the keys last week.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did you lose the keys last week?

PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: Ahmed read two books last month.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: Ahmed didn't read two books last month.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did Ahmed read two books last month?

PastSimpleExs.Negative: She didn't work in Cairo in 2005.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did she work in Cairo in 2005?

PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: You went to the party yesterday
PastSimpleExs.Negative: You didn't go to the party yesterday
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Why didn't you go to the party yesterday?

PastSimpleExs.Ar: انفجرت السيارة في الساعة 9:30 صباحًا الأسبوع الماضي.
PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: The car exploded at 9.30am last week.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: The car didn't explode at 9.30am last week.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did the car explode at 9.30 am last week?

PastSimpleExs.Negative: She didn't go to the door.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did whe go to the door.

PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: We heard the telephone last hour.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: We did not hear the telephone last hour.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did we heard the telephone last hour last hour.

PastSimpleExs.Negative: You didn't watch TV last night.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did you watch TV last night?

PastSimpleExs.Ar: كنت أعيش في هذا المنزل عندما كنت صغيرًا.
PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: I lived in that house when I was young.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: I didn't live in that house when I was young.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did I live in that house when I was young?

PastSimpleExs.Negative: You didn't play tennis last week.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did you play tennis last week?

PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: I lived in Bangkok for 10 years.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: I didn't live in Bangkok for 10 years.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did I live in Bangkok for 10 years?

PastSimpleExs.Affirmative: We sang at the concert last day.
PastSimpleExs.Negative: We did not sing at the concert last day.
PastSimpleExs.Interrogative: Did we sing at the concert last day?

TensesTitles.title: Past Tense
TensesTitles.desc: A tense expressing an action that has happened or a state that previously existed.

TensesTitles.title: Present Tense
TensesTitles.desc: A tense expressing an action that is currently going on or habitually performed, or a state that currently or generally exists.

TensesTitles.title: Future tense
TensesTitles.desc: A tense expressing an action that has not yet happened or a state that does not yet exist.

PastTensesTitles.title: Past Simple
PastTensesTitles.desc: Is a verb tense that is used to talk about things that happened or existed before now.

PastTensesTitles.title: Past Continuous
PastTensesTitles.desc: The past continuous tense, also known as the past progressive tense, refers to a continuing action or state that was happening at some point in the past.

PastTensesTitles.title: Past Perfect
PastTensesTitles.desc: The past perfect continuous tense (also known as the past perfect progressive tense) shows that an action that started in the past continued up until another time in the past.
